awd_abstract_narration:
This proposal funds the research activities of Professors Csaba Csaki, Yuval Grossman, Peter Lepage, Liam McAllister, and Maxim Perelstein at Cornell University.

High-energy physics studies the most fundamental building blocks of matter and their interactions. There are several different ways in which to try to answer the biggest puzzles this field is currently facing.  By colliding elementary particles at the highest energies to date, the Large Hadron Collider (LHC) is expected to yield new clues on the interactions of elementary particles at the shortest distances.  By extremely precise measurements of the cosmic microwave background (CMB) radiation, the properties of the Universe and the type of matter and energy dominating it at early times can be studied.  Finally, powerful computer simulations can be used to study the properties of the strong interactions.  Pursuing all of these directions, the Cornell Particle Theory group will advance the national interest by promoting the advancement of science in one of its most fundamental directions: the discovery and understanding of new physical law.  In his research, Prof. Csaki will develop new models that can explain the origin of mass ("composite Higgs models") and can be tested at the LHC.  The research of Prof. Grossman will focus on the heavier versions of the fundamental particles making up matter (the charm and the bottom quarks) as well as on neutrinos, particles that are created in beta decays.  Prof. Perelstein will investigate new methods by which new particles could be discovered at the LHC, as well as new models for the type of matter (the so-called "dark matter") that surrounds ordinary visible matter, but interacts very weakly with it.  Prof. McAllister will try to characterize the physical laws of the very early Universe by using results from string theory, which is the best candidate for understanding the behavior of the gravitational force at high energies.  Finally, Prof. Lepage will use powerful computer simulations and state-of-the-art techniques to obtain precision results for strongly-interacting matter. This project will also have significant broader impacts. The Cornell particle theory group will train graduate students and involve postdocs in their research, and thereby provide critical training for junior physicists beginning research in this field. They will also give public lectures on their research results, as well as regular lectures to local high-school students. 
 
More technically, Prof. Csaki will investigate new approaches to the hierarchy problem, will examine novel types of Higgs sectors and composite Higgs models, and will study possible experimental tests of vacuum energy, as well as the effects of monopoles in supersymmetric theories.  Prof. Grossman will explore the physics of the intensity frontier, including charm and beauty physics, CP violation, and neutrino physics.  Prof. Perelstein will investigate physics questions that can be addressed with the precision Higgs program at the LHC and future colliders, such as the nature of the electroweak phase transition.  He will also continue to provide theoretical interpretation of the LHC data, and explore novel models of dark matter.  Prof. Lepage, as a co-founder of the HPQCD lattice QCD collaboration, will continue to develop and deploy new techniques for extracting important physics from nonperturbative QCD, with a strong focus on QCD backgrounds that must be analyzed to isolate new physics in heavy-quark physics and very high-precision quantities such as the magnetic moment of the muon.  Prof. McAllister will investigate string theory and early-universe cosmology. He will characterize quantum-gravity constraints on inflation, explore new axion inflation scenarios in string theory, develop tools to compute effective theories in compactifications on Calabi-Yau hypersurfaces, and study the vacuum structure of string theory via random matrix theory.

por.por_cntn:
The research of the Cornell particle theory group, with support from this grant, has advanced our understanding of the fundamental laws that govern the physical world.  The topics studied include the nature and properties of the elementary particles; computation of forces on sub-nuclear scales; candidates for the dark matter that pervades galaxies; and quantum-mechanical theories of gravity.  Research in these directions led to 90 scientific publications during the period of this grant.

Csaki explored the idea that the recently discovered Higgs boson is not an elementary particle but rather a composite object, which could solve some of the mysteries posed by the existence of a light Higgs boson.  In a series of works he introduced the concepts of maximal symmetry and trigonometric parity, which help explain how a composite Higgs boson could be compatible with experimental bounds. Csaki also investigated whether the hypothetical ultra-light axion particle, which could be the dark matter, is affected by short-distance corrections. Finally, Csaki introduced a novel mechanism to explain why the observed universe is so large and empty: in this framework, patches of the universe where the energy density is high are unstable and rapidly collapse.

The LHCb collaboration recently found the first indication  that charm mesons are not the exact mirror images of anti-charm mesons. Grossman studied the theoretical implications of this discovery. In particular, he pointed out that this experimental result confirmed his earlier findings, in which he had suggested that the charm quark should not always be treated as a heavy quark.

Lepage continued his work with the HPQCD collaboration on high-precision simulations of strong interaction physics (QCD). This work, which emphasized the physics of the heavy charm and bottom quarks, provides essential input for a wide variety of experiments in the US, Europe and Asia that are seeking new physics beyond the Standard Model of particle physics.

McAllister made progress in explaining why the observed universe is so much larger than the particles that it contains.  In a series of works, he developed novel mathematical techniques to compute quantum-mechanical effects in string theory.  Using these methods, he found new solutions of string theory that are universes larger than our own.

Perelstein proposed and investigated new ideas for the microscopic composition of dark matter, which is ubiquitous in our universe but cannot be made out of any of the known elementary particles. He also investigated the capabilities of proposed future high-energy collider facilities to search for dark matter and other physics beyond the Standard Model. On the computational side, Perelstein pioneered the use of machine learning-based algorithms to greatly improve the efficiency of Monte Carlo integration and event simulation in high-energy particle physics.

The Cornell group has prioritized broader impacts through education and outreach.  Major accomplishments in this category include the following. Csaki gave a public lecture at the Aspen Center for Physics, which is available on YouTube and has been watched several thousand times. Grossman is working on establishing connections with a Bedouin Center in the Negev desert in Israel. Lepage continued his efforts to promote the use of evidence-based teaching practices in universities. McAllister gave lectures to graduate students at a number of international summer and winter schools, and gave many talks to undergraduates about careers in physics.  Perelstein gave countless presentations on the Cornell physics graduate program to REU students, and during recruitment events.

This grant partially supported 8 postdocs and 15 students.  Many trainees of the Cornell group have gone on to leading postdoctoral and faculty positions.  Others have advanced the technological and economic growth of the nation by applying their scientific training to problems in industry.
